name: luminousmoth

procedures: T1005::[LuminousMoth] has collected files and data from compromised machines.
T1030::[LuminousMoth] has split archived files into multiple parts to bypass a 5MB limit.
T1033::[LuminousMoth] has used a malicious DLL to collect the username from compromised hosts.
T1036.005::[LuminousMoth] has disguised their exfiltration malware as `ZoomVideoApp.exe`.
T1041::[LuminousMoth] has used malware that exfiltrates stolen data to its C2 server.
T1053.005::[LuminousMoth] has created scheduled tasks to establish persistence for their tools.
T1071.001::[LuminousMoth] has used HTTP for C2.
T1083::[LuminousMoth] has used malware that scans for files in the Documents, Desktop, and Download folders and in other drives.
T1091::[LuminousMoth] has used malicious DLLs to spread malware to connected removable USB drives on infected machines.
T1105::[LuminousMoth] has downloaded additional malware and tools onto a compromised host.
T1112::[LuminousMoth] has used malware that adds Registry keys for persistence.
T1204.001::[LuminousMoth] has lured victims into clicking malicious Dropbox download links delivered through spearphishing.
T1539::[LuminousMoth] has used an unnamed post-exploitation tool to steal cookies from the Chrome browser.
T1547.001::[LuminousMoth] has used malicious DLLs that setup persistence in the Registry Key `HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\Current Version\Run`.
T1553.002::[LuminousMoth] has signed their malware with a valid digital signature.
T1557.002::[LuminousMoth] has used ARP spoofing to redirect a compromised machine to an actor-controlled website.
T1560::[LuminousMoth] has manually archived stolen files from victim machines before exfiltration.
T1564.001::[LuminousMoth] has used malware to store malicious binaries in hidden directories on victim's USB drives.
T1566.002::[LuminousMoth] has sent spearphishing emails containing a malicious Dropbox download link.
T1567.002::[LuminousMoth] has exfiltrated data to Google Drive.
T1574.002::[LuminousMoth] has used legitimate executables such as `winword.exe` and `igfxem.exe` to side-load their malware.
T1587.001::[LuminousMoth] has used unique malware for information theft and exfiltration.
T1588.001::[LuminousMoth] has obtained and used malware such as [Cobalt Strike].
T1588.002::[LuminousMoth] has obtained an ARP spoofing tool from GitHub.
T1588.004::[LuminousMoth] has used a valid digital certificate for some of their malware.
T1608.001::[LuminousMoth] has hosted malicious payloads on Dropbox.
T1608.004::[LuminousMoth] has redirected compromised machines to an actor-controlled webpage through HTML injection.
T1608.005::[LuminousMoth] has created a link to a Dropbox file that has been used in their spear-phishing operations.

description: [LuminousMoth](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1014) is a Chinese-speaking cyber espionage group that has been active since at least October 2020. [LuminousMoth](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1014) has targeted high-profile organizations, including government entities, in Myanmar, the Philippines, Thailand, and other parts of Southeast Asia. Some security researchers have concluded there is a connection between [LuminousMoth](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1014) and [Mustang Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0129) based on similar targeting and TTPs, as well as network infrastructure overlaps.(Citation: Kaspersky LuminousMoth July 2021)(Citation: Bitdefender LuminousMoth July 2021)
